In the era where actors who play roles in live-action making blunders during press tours, they came out well and very respectful. Eiichiro Oda involvement definitely the main point why this show works, with showrunners who actually understand the show materials. The production team, from hair and make up, to the set and the musical scores definitely did their best, glad that it shows. Is it perfect? no. It is silly, whacky, and some jokes are hit or miss, but it is fun. We all need some fun to watch in which the whole family can enjoy. As a fan, I'm not the biggest fan of the Garp switch up, but I understand why western writers feels the need to push such grit. Well, I just want to encourage people to give this show a shot because it is just a fun series to fill some weekend movie time.

This show really surprised me. Adaptations of anime are usually pretty bad. I got one episode into Cowboy Bebop before I was out. I never watched the original anime, but I could tell there was just no heart in the adaptation. With One Piece, I also never watched the original, but I know enough about anime to know that season 1 has absolutely mastered taking the ridiculous aspects of anime that make it kind of fun and embracing them, rather than casting them aside. The CGI was better than I expected (making a rubber man is not easy to make look even slightly realistic). The acting was solid. Inaki Godoy (Monkey D. Luffy) was absolutely perfect for this role. His unhinged smile and how much fun he clearly had with the character made what could have been a one-note character work so well. Mackenyu (Roronaoa Zoro) gave a great performance as a stoic samurai. Emily Rudd (Nami) was perfect as well. The showrunners fought the all too common urge nowadays to make the female character perfect. She was flawed, she was complex, she was allowed to be an interesting character. I'm not going to single out actors, but there was one character that gave a very wooden performance that often took me out of the scene, but that is a minor grievance. I watched a few episodes of the anime afterwards, and they were very respectful of the source material. It is not easy to make a good live action anime, but this fun, pirate/samurai/clown/fish-people/stretchy-man show has nailed it. I can't wait for season 2.

A Promising Start: One Piece Live-Action Series Delights with Arlong Park Arc When I first heard that "One Piece" was getting a live-action adaptation, my expectations were tempered with caution. Adapting such a beloved and expansive manga and anime series is no small feat, and many fans, myself included, were worried about how it would translate to the small screen. However, after watching the first season, which covers the Arlong Park arc, I'm thrilled to say that the "One Piece" live-action series has far surpassed my initial expectations. One of the most impressive aspects of this adaptation is the dedication to faithfully recreating Oda's world. The sets, costumes, and visual effects transport viewers to the familiar and fantastic world of the Grand Line. The bustling streets of Cocoyasi Village, the imposing Arlong Park itself, and the eerie depths of the ocean are brought to life with incredible attention to detail. The creators have succeeded in capturing the essence of Oda's imaginative world. One of my biggest concerns was how the characters would be portrayed. The cast of "One Piece" is iconic, and fans have strong attachments to these characters. However, the cast of the live-action series delivers solid performances that capture the essence of their respective roles. The actor portraying Monkey D. Luffy embodies the character's boundless energy and determination, making it easy to root for him. Similarly, the supporting cast, including Nami, Zoro, and Usopp, bring their characters to life with authenticity and charisma. The chemistry between the Straw Hat Pirates is a standout feature of the series. Their interactions feel genuine, and you can sense the camaraderie that makes this crew so endearing. The relationships between characters are explored in depth, adding depth to the story and providing a satisfying emotional resonance. While the live-action adaptation covers only the Arlong Park arc, it manages to capture the heart of "One Piece." The storytelling is faithful to the source material, with a well-paced narrative that allows for character development and world-building. The adaptation doesn't rush through the events, giving viewers a chance to fully immerse themselves in the story and the challenges the Straw Hat Pirates face. The action sequences, while not as grand in scale as some of the later arcs in the manga and anime, are still thrilling and well-executed. The battles at Arlong Park are intense and showcase the physicality and abilities of the characters. The special effects and stunts add to the excitement, and it's clear that the production team invested considerable effort into making these scenes visually engaging. In conclusion, the "One Piece" live-action series, covering the Arlong Park arc, has pleasantly surprised me and left me eagerly awaiting more. It successfully captures the essence of the beloved source material, with strong performances, faithful storytelling, and impressive world-building. While it only scratches the surface of the "One Piece" saga, it's a promising start that bodes well for the future of the series. If you're a fan of "One Piece," this adaptation is a must-watch, and I can't wait to see where it sails next.

I grew up with One Piece, and I have followed the story since 2009. In this sense, nothing comes close to One Piece and it has its own unique vibe even among Shonen manga series like Naruto, Bleach, or Dragon Ball. I followed many other live-action anime adaptations and I always thought it was just impossible to translate them, but I also understood that there was not enough care put into these shows, the best example of this is Death Note which was truly awful, there were made changes that didn't make any sense, it was dry and missed many important things that made this show so popular and amazing, it was outright dumb. There were many changes in One Piece Live Action as well, but these changes were justified, and were smart to condense around 60 episodes of anime into 8 live-action episodes. The cast was just perfect, the music was really good and overall acting was really good, even secondary characters. Attempting to summarize 100 chapters, which is 6 entire arcs of the Manga in just 8 episodes is truly a miracle. When you think about the narrative choices around this Season 1, it was clear that Oda and the team decided to focus on providing as much backstory and character development as possible for Luffy and his initial team of 5 before they set off to the Grand Line. Furthermore, they double-downed on wanting to make sure it was crystal clear what core events/scenarios led them to join Luffy on his adventure. With those 2 key objectives in mind, they cut, trimmed, and adjusted the story to allow for the 2 core story elements to shine while everything around it was a mechanism to tell this tale. Of course, this led to a lot of side characters being completely omitted, introducing key characters earlier, drastically slimming down the number of battle scenes, and changing some aspects of the entire storyline while retaining the core essence of each individual's most pivotal plot point. Now it is easy to point out the flaws, the cringe, the awkwardness, the meh of the Live Action Adaptation but this was an amazing first go at One Piece and I truly hope they continue this Live Action Series because it felt like they had figured out the wrinkles in the story pacing by episode 7/8 and I'm sure Season 2 will surpass Season 1.

Season One: I can honestly say that I'm pretty satisfied with the results. I was a little concerned when I learned that my all time favorite anime was going to get a live action series - even after I learned that Eiichiro Oda was working with the people working on this project, I was still skeptical. But after watching it, I can definitely see the faithfulness to Oda's source materiel while also being a bit more ground; and trying out something a little different. I was pretty happy with the casting choice, as most of the actors did a fantastic job at portraying their respected characters - my favorite being the portrayal of Dracule Mihawk; despite his limited appearances in the anime and manga, he has always been one of my favorite characters (and I was more than happy to see him getting more screen time on this series). And while I did like Mackenyu as Roronoa Zoro, his portrayal at times came off as weak - I get that he was trying to capture the stern and seriousness of Zoro, but he doesn't really have the voice for it just yet, which is why I think he could have used just a bit more energy. And while I√±aki Godoy's acting also came off as weak at times, his personality usually made up for it. I get that there is only so much you can do with real people, and you have so much more room with animation, which is why plenty of stuff was cut out in the first season. But I really wish it had at least ten episodes, if it would have helped for us to see more of the characters we enjoyed and it could have helped build up more of the story - such as Don Krieg, Pearl, Genzo, Nojiko, Cabaji, Merry, Gin, Patty, Mohji, Mayor Boodle, Kuroobi, Choo, and even Arlong's sawblade, or a bit more on the relationships between the crew and their past; as well as the people in their lives. And while there were times when the choreography was obvious, most of the times it was done very well. And I don't object for diversity, just as long as it makes sense. I really do hope that Netflix keeps these people on their payroll, so they can continue bringing this amazing world to life.

The series is watchable. It's not terrible, but it's also not the best adaptation ever made. I have to give credit for being the best live-action adaptation of an anime when compared to what has been done before in this genre. However, compared to the original work, it falls short. This review contains spoilers. I've been following One Piece since I was 14, and since then, I've experienced a lot of emotions in front of my computer screen as I followed this crew and their dynamics through various adventures. I had high hopes for this live-action adaptation based on the interviews, the way the actors interacted, and even the trailer. However, my three stars are only for the first episode and the Arlong saga because the rest is just a downhill slide of frustration. There were some changes I found interesting, like altering the timeline of certain events or introducing characters earlier. However, the series greatly falls short in character development, lacks emotional impact in scenes that should be moving, and consequently, has a shallow plot. There's no time to feel the weight of the scenes and the bonds because the script rushes to deliver as much information as possible, with numerous battle scenes that weren't necessary. Crucial details for creating emotion and defining characters' motivations were simply omitted. For example, in the first episode, before leaving the Conch Town, Luffy picks a fight with Koby precisely so that Koby wouldn't be associated with him because Koby wanted to become a marine (a scene completely removed). Another scene is Sanji's departure from the Baratie: when Sanji leaves, all the chefs are outside to bid farewell, praising his talent, and Sanji kneels and tearfully thanks everyone at Baratie and Chef Zeff, showing how humble Sanji is and how important the Baratie is to his character (another scene poorly adapted). What I mean by bringing up these examples is that they removed what they should have focused on and tried to create punchlines with other scenes that weren't the focus. I think the characters who suffered the most were Zoro and Garp. Two incredible characters who were simply trivialized in the series. Zoro has the charisma of a door in the series, and his motivations have become so selfish that his lines about being part of the crew are empty and make no sense. Seriously, I think the actor only knows how to act like a badass, and it's annoying. Zoro doesn't act like a badass; his actions end up giving that impression, but he's not like that at his core. And the actor is Japanese, grew up with One Piece, and couldn't capture the essence of the character. Garp seems more like a villain, even though his character is the most parental figure in the world of One Piece. It's sad to see how his relationship with Koby developed in the series, especially when in the manga, we had the climax of their relationship, and what Garp meant to Koby and what Koby meant to Garp is completely different. The way the series portrayed his efforts to capture Luffy, when Garp always made sure to leave Luffy alone and never interfere, is painful to watch. In the original work, Garp never supported Luffy, and he was strict, but he would never prevent Luffy's dream like the series depicts. He would never do that! Also, it seems like Garp is emotionally dead in the series, very different from his original personality, which is lively, considering he's the damn hero of the navy. If they had to make someone chase after Luffy in the series, they should have included Smoker because it would have allowed them to skip Loguetown or pass through it more quickly (since the series takes this tone). Above all, One Piece is a political story, built on the relationships within the crew and on each island they visit, as they come into contact with the cruel reality of that world while bringing liberation from suffering because Luffy is a metaphor for freedom. I think what came closest, and I'm being generous, to this was the episode where Usopp joins the crew, and finally the part with Nami. In the Arlong Park arc, we had what would truly be One Piece: they arrive on the island, see the cruelty the people are subjected to, and the crew forms bonds with the people and the town. In summary, I'll continue to watch because it's my favorite show, but it's not all that great. It's just another addition for those who already follow it, and for someone who has never followed or doesn't know anything about One Piece, starting with the series is definitely not recommended.

A brilliant retelling of the legendary manga, the One Piece live action is beautifully done and elevates the source material due to the respect, care and hard work that went into it. As someone who's been reading One Piece religiously for the last 18 years, I can't help but feel great pride that against all odds, One Piece was the show that finally broke the Hollywood anime => live action curse. There was so many things that could have gone wrong, yet they managed to strike the perfect balance of goofiness, seriousness, humour, action and emotion. The world of One Piece is full of colorful and quirky characters, such as Buggy the Clown, a pirate who can detach his body parts; Captain Kuro, a former pirate who faked his death and became a butler; Arlong, a fish-man who rules over a village with an iron fist; and many more. Each episode introduces a new challenge or enemy for Luffy and his crew to overcome, as they travel from one island to another in search of clues and allies. The cast is amazing, especially I√±aki Godoy as Luffy, the main protagonist. He portrays Luffy's personality perfectly: he is cheerful, optimistic, fearless, and loyal to his friends. He also has a unique ability: he can stretch his body like rubber, thanks to eating a mysterious fruit when he was a child. This gives him an edge in combat, but also makes him vulnerable to sharp objects and water. Emily Rudd as Nami, the navigator of Luffy's ship, is also great. She is smart, cunning, and resourceful, but also has a tragic past that makes her sympathetic. She joins Luffy's crew after he helps her free her village from Arlong's tyranny. Mackenyu as Zoro, the swordsman of Luffy's crew, is also impressive. He is a master of the three-sword style, wielding one sword in each hand and one in his mouth. He is fierce and determined, but also has a soft spot for his friends. The show also has amazing visuals and effects. The costumes and sets are faithful to the manga style, creating a vibrant and whimsical atmosphere. The CGI effects are mostly well-done, especially when Luffy uses his stretching powers or when the characters encounter exotic creatures or phenomena. The action scenes are thrilling and well-choreographed, showcasing the skills and abilities of each character. The show is not without flaws, though. Some of the episodes feel rushed or simplified, leaving out some details or explanations that might be important for the plot or the character development. Some of the dialogue is cheesy or clich√©d, relying on common tropes or jokes that might not appeal to everyone. Some of the actors seem to overact or underact in some scenes, creating an inconsistent tone. The show also ends on a cliffhanger that leaves many questions unanswered and many characters unexplored. Overall, though, I think One Piece TV series on Netflix is a fun and entertaining show that anyone can enjoy. It has a lot of humor, heart, action, and adventure that will keep you engaged and curious. I give it 4.5 stars out of 5. I hope Netflix will renew it for a second season soon.

The pacing was off, the fights are weird, this is one piece in name alone. This tv show is like beyond Meat, it's a cheap imitation of something that was a lot better. Bigger spoilers ahead: While much better than Netflix's other attempts at anime adaptation, this one made a lot of mistakes. Stupid camera angles and lenses. Hokey music with "piratey" fifes and crap (why?!), and the original theme song (a true gem that never gets old) was only referenced twice in an overly serious arrangement; almost sapping the fun out of the tune itself. Boo. I do not have any problems with casting! I like all the actors, even all the straw hats. I think they actually fixed Sanji here, so that he's not a complete freaking perv, but that's where a lot of the comedy came from, and because Zoro here is just sooooooooo serious all the time (Zoro is much more dynamic in the source material) there is hardly any comedy to speak of. Nami is portrayed well by a good actor and without misogamy, but without her more bubbly side, she is not as dynamic either. So serious. Ussop is great, less annoying, BUT his character development was greatly cheapened in the adaptation in a crucial way! I'll get to that in a second. And Luffy. I want to state that anyone trying to play this character will disappoint fans. It doesn't matter if they don't smile big like an insane rubber crackhead, or if they have an accent or not, it's because they simply don't have Mayumi Tanaka's voice. NOBODY will ever be more Luffy than Mayumi Tanaka. For 14 years her voice has made us smile, laugh, cry, and think big thoughts about how we should treat people and ourselves. So, this kid is going to disappoint and that's nobody's fault. But he does an amazing job of it. He's charismatic, optimistic, determined, and protective of his nakama. But I do think he portrays a Luffy who is too smart, experiencing too much self doubt, and who is too weak while being too stoic. I like that he focused on creating someone who is 100% concerned with goodness and dreams and smiled a lot, and also listens a lot. Luffy listens to people when it counts. So I hope that folks who haven't seen the anime can appreciate his hard work and talent more than I can, because it's just so hard not to be distracted by how different Luffy is here. As for Ussop, I like the actor a lot. I think he's dynamic and portrays a less annoying Ussop, though much less funny. One of the biggest problems with this adaptation was how they crammed Arlong Park into one episode, and one thing that suffered from that was Ussop's development. He is supposed to be a coward. He is supposed to get chased down by Chew, beaten to hell and feel ashamed of how weak he is, how useless to his friends he is. He is supposed to push past that fear and doubt and shame and DEFEAT a much much stronger opponent regardless of how implausible it is. And at the end of it, he screams from the flat of his back that he can win fights! Not to look down on him. He proves his worth to his opponent and himself. And we, the reader/watcher, are feeling a kind of payoff here like it was a letter from Oda to all the outcasts and freaks out there who feel totally unequipped to be of use, totally unworthy of friendship and love. That we too can do it. We can win, we can help our friends. This adaptation shortened the fight to a few minutes, removed ALL of the pain and danger from it, the comedy, and when Ussop delivers his victory line, he's standing unharmed, and he says something that vaguely resembles what Oda wrote, but twisted into another one of Ussop's stupid lies, only showing us that even when nobody's watching his ego needs to be fed. I think this is the wrong way to portray Ussop. Similarly to Ussop's fight, Luffy's fight with Arlong was shortened a bunch, sanitized of almost any pain or danger whatsoever, and showed a much less creative couple of combatants. Much, much less creative. Part of that is because in the source material Luffy and Arlong are much closer to being equals in physical might, so things get funky and wild. But here? Luffy is much weaker than Arlong so he tricks him into destroying his own home, and the collapse kills Arlong, the stronger one, but not Luffy, the weaker one? Really? And no biting? No nose break? No dagger dentures? What? This is supposed to be a fantastically unrealistic story. You're supposed to barely see Luffy's fists coming. He's supposed to be an insane dude obsessed with fighting. If they did away with the unneeded Garp beat down, they could have spent more time on Arlong Park and done it justice, but they instead made it boring and weird. Sanji/kuroobi, and zoro/hachi fights were criminally re-written, a 1/10 compared to the anime. Arlong realizing how dangerous Zoro is was one of the cooler parts of the fight in the source material. Seeing the kind of insane willpower Zoro has to remain alive and useful even after receiving what Arlong thinks is a mortal wound from Mihawk. Resolving to kill him then and there because Zoro poses such a threat to him if he were to heal and continue living. And not to mention.... hey.....NO "SWITCH!?!?!" What the heck! No switch?!?!?! That whole piece is missing!? This whole thing was too grounded, too short, and too serious, though the visual effects were great. There is nothing wrong with the casting or anyone's accents, genders, or race. The One Piece world does not exist, so....whatever. Don't cry about how many extra's weren't white or whatever. If you ask me, I'm excited to see how season 2 continues to fix Zoro's seeming racial bias that one could point out in the anime at times. And I'm also grateful that the adaptation is much less likely to obsess over titties as much as the source material does down the line, but, what the adaptation can possibly "fix" with the anime may not be enough to win Netflix any more stars from me based on how much it got wrong and/or simply didn't bother to include. The series needed a minimum of one more episode, preferably two to be done better. Netflix...! Arlong Park is an epic conclusion to the biggest arc in the series up that point. Sheesh.

I had every reason to believe that Netflix's One Piece adaptation would be a collosal piece of garbage. They have done nothing but give me reason after reason with their awful takes on Cowboy Bebop, and the Witcher to not trust them to do an adaptation properly, and just when I was completely done with them they pull off One Piece. It makes no sense, but this is the wild and crazy world we live in. Now granted, One Piece is actually impossible to adapt COMPLETELY to the live screen, anyone even casually familiar with the source material will understand that, but goddamn this show does as good of a job as can be reasonably expected to bring the world and characters to life. The casting is great. These might be relatively newcomer actors, but they give the kinds of performances that make it look like they have been waiting their entire lives to bring these characters to life. I√±aki Godoy in particular gets a standing ovation from me for how close he nailed Luffy. We get actual sets and make up and not just an overabundance of CGI which is a nice thing to see. The writing and directing does an admirable job of not only adjusting the pace to make it fit in live action, which any One Piece fan could tell you was going to be a challenge, but also not shying away from the original style of the manga. There's a side by side comparison of one of the fights in the series, I wont say which one to keep this review spoiler free, that shows just how closely the choreography was being tailored to fit the action in the anime. I do still have some nitpicks about certain adjustments that don't seem to be neccessary but they're not major gripes as much as minor nitpicks. All of my praise being said, this show still might not click for everyone. The subject matter is goofy and kind of cheesy at times, but hey it wouldn't be One Piece if it wasn't. I have to give Netflix my genuine appreciation for this one. They did this one right. I'm quick to tell them when they screw things up, (just read my Witcher review) so it's only fair I praise them when they get it right.

True to its manga origins, and filmed in homage to the style of the anime, "One Piece" does a wonderful job of recreating what is one of Japan's most historic and ingenious works of fiction. The show has a youthful charm, is appropriately silly and is extremely "Woke", but can be forgiven for the later, due to the respect it gives its roots. It's extremely rare to see media stay true to form, as producers, directors and the requirements of filming often interfere with any authenticity a story might have as filming progresses. The small deviations this show does take are done in such good taste, that it can even be argued that they improve the story. It's difficult to ask this show to reproduce the frenetic fight scenes and rapid pace of its predecessor, the Japanese anime. To do so would require a higher bar in terms of emotional performance as well as action sequence. The anime presents incredibly exaggerated expressions and gestures thru creative vantage points. It's very wise of developers Matt Owens and Steven Maeda to forego these requirements in this live-action remake, allowing the series to come down to Earth, while still delivering excitement and laughter to its audience! The cinematographers do a commendable job filming, and all other aspects of the show (including script, plot and sound) are delivered professionally, even down to each line being clearly spoken. "One Piece" is about friendship, character, and skill. It's also about over-the-top villains and down-to-Earth protagonists. Monkey D. Luffy's infectious confidence inspires others; he searches their hearts for their one true desire, and helps them achieve it. As such, he is a true hero, despite the clingy, brown-nose style this series exaggerates in his character. Sadly, the decision to include blood and gore in this show seriously detracts from its ability to be family friendly. Despite this setback, "One Piece" delivers on its goofy, action-packed premise, and is a great popcorn flick / series for parties and get togethers.
